ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: During this semester, I expanded my basic knowledge of German grammar, oral skills, writing capabilities, and vocabulary.
I learned German and I learned some about German culture. Really, that's about it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: -the material is designed to expand your basic vocabulary so we are able to have daily conversations Weaknesses: -the material is much more rigorous in terms of grammar
Sometimes topics seem irrelevant (the unit on fairy tales)

I felt like a lot of grammar was taught this semester, but none of it from a practical standpoint. In my opinion, grammar is most effectively taught using examples rather than rules so that students can understand the context in which it might fall in everyday conversation. Rather, the grammar was taught from a prescriptive, rule-following standpoint, which a) is not as useful and b) leaves out the millions of exceptions that occur in German.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would without a doubt recommend this course to another student, as this is the most challenging and rewarding class I have taken.
Yes and take it with Thorsten! Semi useful but something that is not spanish or French and the department isnt a pushover but also isnt too hard

I mean, as languages here go I think German is among the more laid-back ones. The professors are very good about giving feedback and understanding that students may not learn a new language so quickly at this age.
